Lake District Offers The Lakes' Finest Hotels Welcome to Lake District Offers, your one-stop destination for uncovering the best deals and exclusive offers in the enchanting Lake District! As one of the UK’s most cherished natural wonders, the Lake District boasts picturesque landscapes, stunning views, shimmering lakes, and charming towns that attract visitors from all over the world. Our mission is to help you explore this captivating region without breaking the bank. At Lake District Offers, we have meticulously curated a selection of unbeatable deals and discounts on accommodation, dining experiences, outdoor activities, and local attractions, ensuring you make the most of your time in this breathtaking region. Whether you’re seeking a cosy B&B for a romantic getaway, a family-friendly hotel, or an adrenaline-pumping adventure, we have something for everyone. With our easy-to-navigate website and dedicated team of experts, planning your dream Lake District holiday has never been simpler. So immerse yourself in the natural beauty of the Lake District, and let us take care of the rest. Welcome to the adventure of a lifetime! Lake District Offers - Latest News & Guides The Top Dog-Friendly Pubs in the Lake District Discover the Best Mountains to Climb in the UK Lake District Big Cats: Unravelling the Mystery England Expands Wild Swimming Sites Your Ultimate Guide to the Lake District Experience Nestled amidst the scenic mountains and serene countryside, the Lake District beckons tourists from all walks of life. Whether it’s the breathtaking views, the thrill of exploration, or a relaxing weekend getaway you’re after, this region offers something for everyone. Enter LakeDistrictOffers.com, your one-stop portal for every holiday need in this picturesque region. Discover Unbeatable Deals and Discounts No longer do you need to scour the internet for the best deals. With a plethora of promotions and packages readily available on LakeDistrictOffers.com, your dream holiday is just a click away. From discounted luxury hotels accommodations to enticing package deals, there’s something to fit every budget and preference. Unparalleled Accommodations Choose from a range of breaks and accommodations that the Lake District has to offer. Be it a quaint countryside cottage or a luxury resort with views of the fells and the mountains; there’s a place for everyone. With exclusive deals and vouchers, rest assured you’re getting the best bang for your buck. Diverse Activities and Attractions Hikers and cycling lovers will find themselves spoilt for choice with the multitude of trails and paths meandering through the lush landscapes. Those looking for a bit of adventure can delve into boating, while fishing enthusiasts can bask in the tranquility that the region’s lakes offer. And if you’re in the mood for a more relaxed exploration, there are countless attractions that highlight the rich history and culture of the Lake District. The Best of Nature and Wildlife The Lake District is a haven for nature lovers. Witness the diverse wildlife in their natural habitat and get up close and personal with the flora that adorns the region. The pristine lakes, rolling mountains, and sprawling countryside serve as a gentle reminder of nature’s marvels. Weekend Breaks and Getaways Short on time? No worries! LakeDistrictOffers.com boasts a wide range of weekend breaks and getaways. Whether it’s a brief respite from the hustle and bustle or an extended holiday, you’re guaranteed to find a package that resonates with you. All-in-one Adventure The true beauty of LakeDistrictOffers.com lies in its all-encompassing nature. Not only does it offer discounts and vouchers, but it also brings together the best of what the Lake District has in terms of breaks, activities, attractions, and natural beauty. From relaxation to adventure, from hiking to boating, this website ensures that every visitor can curate their perfect holiday experience. In conclusion, if the Lake District is on your bucket list (and it should be), then LakeDistrictOffers.com is the resource you shouldn’t miss. Providing unparalleled deals, promotions, and information on the region’s best, this website ensures that every traveler can craft their ideal Lake District adventure. So, pack your bags, grab those vouchers, and embark on a journey of exploration and relaxation amidst the beauty of nature. Introduction to The Lake District The Lake District, also known as “The Lakes” or “Lakeland”, is a mountainous region in North West England. It’s famed for its picturesque scenery, comprising forests, mountains and lakes, and has been an inspiration for numerous poets, writers, and artists over the centuries. Here’s an introduction to this beautiful region: Geographical Overview: Located in the county of Cumbria, the Lake District covers an area of approximately 2,362 square kilometers. It is home to England’s deepest lake, Wastwater, and its highest mountain, Scafell Pike. National Park Status: In 1951, the Lake District was designated as a national park. It’s England’s largest national park and welcomes millions of visitors every year. Literary Heritage: The region has inspired many literary figures, most notably William Wordsworth, who was born in Cockermouth and later lived in Grasmere. Other notable figures include Samuel Taylor Coleridge, Robert Southey, and Beatrix Potter, the latter of whom was also an avid conservationist and left a significant portion of her land to the National Trust. Activities: It’s a haven for outdoor enthusiasts, offering activities like hiking, rock climbing, kayaking, and mountain biking. The region is crisscrossed with walking trails ranging from easy lakeside strolls to challenging mountain hikes. Fauna and Flora: The Lake District is rich in biodiversity. From the red squirrel to the peregrine falcon, its habitats provide a refuge for many native species. The region’s flora includes the iconic bluebell woods and upland heath areas. Cultural Significance: The Lakes have a rich cultural history, from ancient stone circles to historic houses and gardens. The region also hosts numerous festivals, events, and farmers’ markets throughout the year. World Heritage Site: In 2017, the Lake District was awarded UNESCO World Heritage Site status, recognized for its scenic beauty and its role in shaping the conservation movement in the UK. Towns and Villages: Amidst the vast landscapes are charming towns and villages. Keswick, Ambleside, and Windermere are some of the popular hubs for visitors. Each offers unique attractions, from museums and theaters to quaint shops and traditional pubs. Conservation Efforts: The balance between tourism and conservation is a constant focus in the region. Many initiatives are in place to preserve the natural beauty and cultural heritage of the Lakes, from sustainable tourism practices to rewilding projects. Getting There: The Lake District is well-connected by road and rail. The M6 motorway runs to the east, and train services frequently connect to Windermere and other towns from major cities. In conclusion, the Lake District is a blend of natural beauty, rich history, and cultural significance. Whether you’re an adventurer, a literature enthusiast, or simply seeking tranquility, the Lakes have something to offer everyone. Accommodation Options Accommodation in the Lake District caters to a variety of tastes and budgets. Here’s an overview of the options available to visitors: Hotels: Luxury Hotels: For those seeking opulence, there are several upscale hotels offering spa facilities, gourmet dining, and rooms with breathtaking views. Some historic estates and mansions have been converted into luxury accommodations. - Boutique Hotels: Smaller hotels with unique decor, providing a more intimate experience. - Budget Hotels: For travelers watching their expenses, numerous budget hotels offer basic amenities but still ensure a comfortable stay. - Bed & Breakfasts and Guest Houses: Commonly found throughout the region, B&Bs provide a homely atmosphere. Many are family-run, offering a more personalized experience. These establishments often serve a hearty breakfast, ensuring a great start to your day of exploration. - Self-Catering Cottages & Apartments: Perfect for those who prefer independence during their stay. The Lake District has a wide range of self-catering options, from cozy stone cottages to modern apartments. This option is especially popular among families and groups. - Hostels: There are several youth hostels in the Lake District, operated by organizations like the YHA (Youth Hostel Association). They offer shared dormitory-style rooms, making them an affordable choice for solo travelers, backpackers, and young visitors. - Camping & Caravanning: For those who love to be close to nature, the Lake District has numerous campsites. Whether you’re bringing a tent, caravan, or motorhome, you’ll find sites with varying levels of facilities. There are also “wild camping” opportunities in certain areas, though it’s essential to follow local guidelines and practice Leave No Trace principles. - Glamping: A blend of glamour and camping, glamping offers a more comfortable outdoor experience. Options range from safari tents and yurts to eco-pods and treehouses, often equipped with beds, electricity, and sometimes even heating. - Farm Stays: Experience rural life by staying on a working farm. It’s a unique opportunity to get close to animals and understand the farming culture in the region. Many farm stays also offer fresh produce and homemade meals. - Country Inns and Pubs: Several traditional inns and pubs in the Lake District provide rooms or suites. Staying in such establishments offers a taste of local life, often accompanied by delicious traditional meals and a chance to mingle with locals. - Lodges and Log Cabins: Nestled in forests or by the lakeside, these accommodations offer a serene and rustic experience. Many come with modern amenities like hot tubs, making them perfect for a romantic getaway. - Historic & Unique Stays: From old watermills to castles, the Lake District has several properties that have been converted into unique accommodation options. They provide a distinctive experience, immersing guests in the region’s history. - When booking accommodation in the Lake District, especially during peak tourist seasons, it’s advisable to book well in advance. Regardless of where you choose to stay, the stunning landscapes and rich heritage of the area ensure an unforgettable experience. Outdoor Activities and Adventure Sports The Lake District’s diverse landscapes, from its tranquil lakes to rugged fells, make it a prime destination for outdoor enthusiasts. Here are some of the top outdoor activities and adventure sports you can engage in while visiting the region: Walking & Hiking: Fell Walking: The Lake District is home to many ‘fells’ (mountains or hills), including Scafell Pike, England’s highest peak. There are trails suitable for all levels, from challenging ascents to more leisurely walks. - Lakeside Walks: Trails that skirt the edges of the lakes, offering picturesque views. - Cycling & Mountain Biking: There are numerous cycle routes across the Lake District. Grizedale Forest, for example, offers a range of tracks for both family cycling and adrenaline-pumping downhill trails. - Rock Climbing & Bouldering: The rugged terrain provides numerous opportunities for climbers. Whether you’re a beginner or an expert, there are spots like Shepherds Crag in Borrowdale or the Langdale Boulders to challenge yourself. - Water Sports: Kayaking & Canoeing: Paddle through the serene waters of lakes such as Derwentwater or Coniston Water. - Sailing: Windermere and Ullswater are popular lakes for sailing enthusiasts. - Stand Up Paddleboarding (SUP): A more recent trend that’s gaining popularity in the area. - Wild Swimming: Dive into the refreshing waters of the Lake District’s lakes, tarns, and rivers. Popular spots include Rydal Water and Wastwater. - Fishing: With a permit, one can fish for trout, salmon, and pike in many of the region’s lakes and rivers. - Horse Riding: Explore the countryside on horseback, with several stables offering guided rides for both beginners and experienced riders. - Caving & Potholing: Discover the subterranean wonders of the Lake District. While it’s not as famous for its caves as other regions, there are still opportunities like Cathedral Quarry or Penny Rock Wood for the underground enthusiasts. - Paragliding & Hang Gliding: For those seeking an aerial view, the Lake District’s high fells offer launching spots to soar over the scenic vistas. - Boat Tours and Cruises The Lake District’s shimmering lakes are central to its appeal, and what better way to experience them than on a boat? Whether you’re seeking a relaxed scenic cruise, a practical means of transport, or a private boating experience, there’s something for everyone. Here’s an overview of boat tours and cruises in the Lake District: Windermere Lake Cruises: Windermere is England’s largest lake and offers a variety of cruises. - Hop-on, hop-off services allow visitors to explore lakeside attractions like the World of Beatrix Potter, Wray Castle, and Brockhole. - Themed evening cruises, such as jazz or buffet cruises, are available during the summer months. - Ullswater ‘Steamers’: These boats, some over a century old, provide cruises on the beautiful Ullswater lake. - The service connects Pooley Bridge, Glenridding, Howtown, and Aira Force, allowing for lovely walks between stops. - Offers stunning views of Helvellyn and the surrounding fells. - Coniston Water Cruises: The steam yacht ‘Gondola’ is a fully-restored Victorian boat offering cruises on Coniston Water. - It provides an elegant boating experience with saloons and plush seating. - Stops include Brantwood, the home of John Ruskin, and allows passengers to explore the lake’s history and scenic beauty. - Derwentwater Launches: Located near Keswick, the launches on Derwentwater provide both regular transport services and scenic cruises. - The circular route has several landing stages, including the Lodore Falls and the Lingholm Estate. - It’s popular for combining boat rides with walks in the surrounding area. - Keswick Launch: Another option on Derwentwater, Keswick Launch offers a 50-minute cruise around the lake with commentary highlighting points of interest. - There’s also an option to hop on and off, exploring attractions like the Theatre by the Lake. - Private Boat Hire: For those seeking a more personal experience, several marinas and boat centers across the lakes offer private boat rentals. - Options range from motorboats and rowing boats to electric boats and canoes. - This allows visitors to chart their course and explore the lakes at their own pace. - Specialty Cruises & Events: Some companies offer themed cruises for special occasions, including weddings, birthdays, and corporate events. - Others might offer sunset cruises, wildlife spotting tours, or even guided fishing trips. - Canoe and Kayak Tours: For the more adventurous, guided canoe or kayak tours are available on various lakes. This offers a more immersive and intimate lake experience, often combined with historical and environmental insights. - When considering a boat tour or cruise, it’s essential to check the schedule, especially during off-peak seasons, as services might be reduced or altered. Don’t forget to pack some weather-appropriate clothing, as it can get chilly on the water, even during warmer months. Most importantly, enjoy the breathtaking views, the gentle sway of the boat, and the tranquil ambiance of the Lake District’s waters. Hiking and Walking Trails The Lake District, with its combination of serene lakes and rugged fells, is a paradise for hikers and walkers. The region offers trails that cater to all levels, from gentle lakeside strolls to challenging mountain hikes. Here are some of the most iconic and recommended trails in the area: Scafell Pike: As England’s highest peak, Scafell Pike is a must-hike for many. The trail offers breathtaking panoramic views, but it’s a challenging hike best suited for those with some hiking experience. Several routes lead to the summit, with the route from Wasdale Head being one of the most popular. - Helvellyn via Striding Edge: This is one of the most thrilling hikes in the Lake District. Striding Edge is a sharp ridge leading to Helvellyn’s summit. The trail requires a head for heights, but the views are rewarding. - Catbells: A relatively short hike, Catbells is popular among families and offers stunning views of Derwentwater and Keswick. It’s an excellent introduction to Lake District fells. - Old Man of Coniston: This trail takes you to the summit of the Old Man, passing through old quarry workings and offering panoramic views of the surrounding fells and Coniston Water. - Grasmere Lake & Rydal Water Circuit: A more leisurely walk, this circuit takes you around two beautiful lakes, passing by historical sites like Dove Cottage, once home to poet William Wordsworth. - Langdale Pikes: This hike explores the craggy peaks of Harrison Stickle, Pavey Ark, and others. The Dungeon Ghyll path is commonly used and offers striking vistas of the Langdale Valley. - Orrest Head: A short and relatively easy climb from Windermere, Orrest Head is where Alfred Wainwright, the famous fellwalker and author, first fell in love with the Lake District. The view encompasses a panorama of the central Lake District fells. - Buttermere Circuit: This is a gentle walk around the serene Buttermere lake, offering picturesque views of the surrounding fells, including Fleetwith Pike and Haystacks. - Haystacks: A favorite of Alfred Wainwright, this moderate hike leads to the charming summit of Haystacks, providing views of Buttermere, Crummock Water, and the surrounding peaks. - Easedale Tarn from Grasmere: A lovely walk leading to a mountain tarn, it passes through picturesque countryside and offers views of waterfalls and rugged crags. - Castlerigg Stone Circle: - This short walk from Keswick leads to an ancient stone circle, offering both historical intrigue and panoramic views of the surrounding fells. - Ambleside to Troutbeck and Back via Wansfell: - This trail provides lovely views of Windermere and the surrounding area, passing through the charming village of Troutbeck. - Safety Tips: Always check the weather forecast before heading out. - Inform someone of your planned route and expected return time. - Carry essential gear, including a map, compass, waterproof clothing, food, and water. - Stick to the marked paths and respect the environment. - Whether you’re seeking solitude, a family-friendly trail, or a challenging fell-top adventure, the Lake District has a wealth of hiking and walking trails to offer, each providing its unique experience and perspective on this stunning landscape. Heritage Sites and Historical Attractions The Lake District, in addition to its natural beauty, boasts a rich tapestry of history and heritage. From ancient stone circles and Roman fortifications to the homes of literary greats, the region offers a diverse range of historical attractions. Here’s a selection of some of the notable heritage sites and historical points of interest: Castlerigg Stone Circle: Located near Keswick, this Neolithic stone circle dates back to around 3000 BC. It’s one of the oldest in Britain and offers panoramic views of the surrounding fells. - Hadrian’s Wall: While not directly in the Lake District, this UNESCO World Heritage Site is a short drive away. Built by the Romans in the 2nd century AD, parts of the wall and associated forts can be explored. - Muncaster Castle: Situated near Ravenglass, this historic castle has been in the Pennington family for over 800 years. It offers beautiful gardens, a hawk and owl center, and ghostly legends. - Hill Top: The former home of Beatrix Potter, located in Near Sawrey. It’s been preserved as it was when she lived there, offering a glimpse into the life of the beloved author and conservationist. - Dove Cottage: Located in Grasmere, this was the home of poet William Wordsworth from 1799 to 1808. It’s now a museum dedicated to his life and work. - Blackwell, The Arts & Crafts House: Overlooking Lake Windermere, this house is a gem of Arts & Crafts architecture. It retains many original features and offers insight into the Arts & Crafts movement. - Furness Abbey: Located in Barrow-in-Furness, these impressive ruins were once one of the richest Cistercian monasteries in England. The site offers a tranquil exploration of medieval architecture. - Hardknott Roman Fort: Perched on the western side of the Hardknott Pass, these Roman ruins provide a sense of the ancient history of the region, complemented by dramatic views. - Sizergh Castle & Garden: Near Kendal, this historic estate includes a medieval house filled with Elizabethan interiors and a notable collection of portraits and furniture. The gardens are also a highlight. - Windermere Jetty, Museum of Boats, Steam, and Stories: This modern museum on the shores of Windermere delves into the lake’s boating history, showcasing a collection of boats that tell stories of life on the lake. - Lanercost Priory: - Founded in 1169, this Augustinian priory boasts a picturesque and peaceful setting. Its history is intertwined with the tumultuous Border raids and the construction of Hadrian’s Wall. - Stott Park Bobbin Mill: - Located near Finsthwaite, this industrial heritage site offers insight into the region’s industrial past. It produced millions of wooden bobbins crucial for Lancashire’s spinning and weaving industries. - When visiting these sites, it’s often beneficial to take guided tours or use informational booklets when available, as they provide richer context and historical background. These attractions not only offer a journey through time but also often come with the added bonus of being set against the backdrop of the Lake District’s stunning landscapes. Wildlife and Nature Reserves The Lake District’s rich mosaic of habitats – from its lakes and woodlands to fells and moorlands – offers sanctuary to a myriad of wildlife species. For nature enthusiasts, the region offers several reserves and areas where wildlife thrives. Here’s an overview of some prominent wildlife and nature reserves in the Lake District: Leighton Moss RSPB Reserve: Located slightly to the south of the Lake District near Silverdale, Leighton Moss is the largest reedbed in north-west England. It’s home to a variety of bird species, including bitterns, marsh harriers, and bearded tits. Otters can also be spotted in its lagoons. - Haweswater and Naddle Forest: This area is the only place in England where golden eagles can be found. The RSPB manages a viewpoint at Haweswater for those hoping to catch a glimpse of these magnificent birds. - Ennerdale Valley: A quieter part of the Lake District, Ennerdale is a haven for red squirrels, birds of prey, and diverse plant species. The valley is undergoing rewilding, which allows natural processes to shape the land and habitats. - Dove Stone Reserve: Managed by the RSPB and located on the edge of the Peak District, this area is a mixture of upland heath and blanket bog. It’s home to species like the peregrine falcon, golden plover, and the rare mountain hare. - Smardale Gill Nature Reserve: A picturesque reserve with a mix of woodland, grassland, and disused railway tracks. It’s home to the Scotch Argus butterfly, red squirrels, and various bird species. - South Walney Nature Reserve: Located near Barrow-in-Furness, this coastal reserve is home to a vast grey seal colony. Various seabirds can be spotted here, and the shingle islands provide nesting grounds. - Eycott Hill Nature Reserve: Managed by Cumbria Wildlife Trust, this area comprises wetlands, woodlands, and grasslands. It’s a hotspot for dragonflies, damselflies, and various wildflowers. - Dubwath Silver Meadows: This wetland reserve is located near Bassenthwaite Lake and is a haven for birds, butterflies, and wildflowers. - Red Deer and Fell Ponies: The Lake District’s higher fells and moorlands are home to England’s only truly wild population of red deer. Fell ponies, a native breed, can also be spotted grazing on higher ground. - Brockhole on Windermere: While primarily known as a visitor center, Brockhole has lovely gardens that attract various bird species, and the shoreline offers chances to spot waterfowl. - Tips for Wildlife Watching: Patience and Quietness: Many animals are shy and will remain hidden if they sense human presence. Be patient, and you might be rewarded with a sighting. - Dawn and Dusk: These are often the best times to spot wildlife, as many species are more active during these periods. - Guided Walks: Consider joining a guided walk. Local experts can provide insights and increase your chances of wildlife spotting. - Leave No Trace: Respect the habitats and wildlife. Do not disturb animals or their homes. - The Lake District’s diverse habitats ensure that it remains one of the best places in England for wildlife enthusiasts, providing a unique blend of mountain, forest, and water ecosystems. Local Cuisine and Dining Options The Lake District, with its rich agricultural heritage and abundant natural resources, boasts a variety of traditional foods and contemporary dining experiences. Whether you’re after hearty traditional fare or gourmet delights, the region caters to all tastes. Here’s a selection of local cuisine and dining options: Traditional Foods: Cumberland Sausage: A robust, coiled sausage made from seasoned pork. It’s so intrinsic to the region that it has been granted Protected Geographical Indication (PGI) status. - Grasmere Gingerbread: A cross between a cookie and cake, this spicy-sweet treat was created in Grasmere by Sarah Nelson in the 19th century. - Kendal Mint Cake: A glucose-based confection flavoured with peppermint, it’s famously known as the energy-rich snack carried by mountaineers and explorers. - Damson Jam: The Lyth and Winster valleys in the Lake District are known for their damson orchards. The small, plum-like fruits are turned into jams, jellies, and even gin. - Lakeland Tattie Pot: A hearty stew made with mutton or lamb, black pudding, and potatoes. - Rum Butter: A rich concoction of rum, butter, sugar, and spices, traditionally served at christenings. - Sticky Toffee Pudding: A moist sponge cake made with dates and drenched in toffee sauce. While its origins are debated, it’s a favourite in many Lake District pubs and restaurants. - Dining Options: Pubs & Inns: Traditional pubs abound in the Lake District, offering hearty fare in cosy, historic settings. Pubs like “The Drunken Duck” in Ambleside or “The Masons Arms” in Cartmel Fell are known for their traditional ambience and delicious food. - Tearooms & Cafés: Perfect for afternoon snacks or a lunch stop during a hike. The “Flock-In” at the Herdy Shop in Keswick or “Baldry’s Tea Room” in Grasmere are just a couple of examples. - Fine Dining: The Lake District boasts several Michelin-starred restaurants, showcasing the best of local ingredients. “L’Enclume” in Cartmel and “The Forest Side” in Grasmere are two notable establishments that have received high acclaim. - Farm Shops: These offer some of the freshest local produce. “Low Sizergh Barn” near Kendal has its farm shop selling everything from cheeses to meats, and there’s also a café on-site. - Seafood: Due to its proximity to the coast, fresh seafood is often available. Restaurants near the western edge of the Lake District, closer to the Irish Sea, frequently feature fresh catches on their menus. - International Cuisine: Alongside traditional British fare, you can find a variety of international cuisines, from Italian to Indian, in the larger towns of the Lake District. - Local Breweries & Distilleries: The Lakes is home to several breweries and distilleries. “The Lakes Distillery” produces whisky, gin, and vodka, while breweries like “Hawkshead Brewery” offer craft beers inspired by the region. - When visiting the Lake District, it’s a treat to immerse oneself in the local flavours, enjoying both the traditional dishes that have been passed down through generations and the contemporary interpretations offered by modern chefs.

column32: Fairly large youth hostel, very clean and professional, operated by the Dutch affiliate of Hostelling International. Next to the pleasant Vondelpark, puts you on the southern side of downtown and just a few blocks from the Van Gogh Museum and the Rijksmuseum. The breakfast is filling and has a social atmosphere. This location is popular with school groups. Bring a padlock for your locker, or purchase one at the desk. Stayokay Amsterdam Vondelpark is one of the largest and most up-to-date hostels in Europe. It has a unique location on the famous Vondelpark, the green heart of the city, and a stone’s throw from Leidseplein, the city’s shopping streets, museums and vibrant nightlife. Enjoy the historic buildings and the beautiful museums. Take a boat trip through the canals, walk through the city parks and shop in the old town. Stayokay Amsterdam Vondelpark is located right in the center of the city. The famous Vondelpark is right on the doorstep. Near the hostel you will find Leidseplein, Museumplein and various well-known shopping streets. In the hostel The atmosphere reflects the lively atmosphere in the rest of Amsterdam. The hostel has spacious dorms and private rooms, each with its own bathroom. You can enjoy a delicious meal and a drink in the trendy bar and restaurant. There are also plenty of nice seating areas to relax or meet other travelers. Many activities are organized at the hostel. How about a singer songwriter, game or a sustainability event? Speaking of sustainable, we also separate waste and help with green projects in the neighborhood! Reviews are important. For you and for us. It helps you to make the right choice and helps us to learn. That is why we post reviews on external (booking) sites on our own website. Want to know more? Click here. Guests receive an email after their stay to leave a review. The scores are calculated by means of an analysis of the written review and are based on the past 12 months. Written reviews are summarised because we cannot show them in full due to copyright issues. But positive or negative, we post them all. We do not pay for reviews and fake reviews are reported. Sentiment Facilities 8.2 based on 3252 reviews Food 9 based on 852 reviews Cleanliness 9 based on 1144 reviews Ambience 6.7 based on 392 reviews Service 9.4 based on 921 reviews Location 9.4 based on 1550 reviews Value 6.4 based on 580 reviews De recensies komen van websites als Booking.com, Tripadvisor, Google, Expedia.com en Priceline. Family, May 2024 ★ ★ ★ ★ The guest appreciated the food. Couple from Italy, May 2024 ★ ★ ★ ★ ★ The guest appreciated the housekeeping, the bedroom, the surrounding area, and the breakfast. Was less satisfied by value for money and the personnel. (School) group from Spain, May 2024 ★ ★ ★ ★ The guest appreciated the checkin, the bedroom, the surrounding area, the bathroom, the reception, the sound, and the bar. Was less satisfied by the hygiene and the personnel. Couple from Argentina, May 2024 ★ ★ ★ ★ ★ The guest was less satisfied by the personnel. Guest, May 2024 ★ ★ ★ ★ ★ The guest appreciated the breakfast, the sound, the personnel, the bedroom, and the housekeeping. Family, May 2024 ★ ★ ★ ★ The guest appreciated the bedroom and the housekeeping. Was less satisfied by value for money. Friend group, May 2024 ★ ★ ★ ★ The guest appreciated value for money, the bedroom, the surrounding area, and the reception. Solo traveller from Portugal, May 2024 ★ ★ ★ ★ The guest appreciated the breakfast and the bedroom. Guest, May 2024 What people say Amazing hostel Very clean and tidy Wonderful rooms Excellent service Very fair prices Nice bathrooms Satisfying restaurant Nice breakfast Who said it 33% Solo travellers 30% (School) groups 22% Families 11% Couples Route & location Public transport From Central Station or Schiphol Airport From Amsterdam Centraal Station you can take tram lines 2, 11 or 12 to the Leidseplein stop; from Sloterdijk Station take tram 19 to Leidseplein. From here you will see the Hotel Marriott; walk to your left when facing the main entry and proceed towards the Vondelpark, we are located on Zandpad 5, next to the main entrance of the park. The walk takes about 3 minutes. From Schiphol Airport, take the Connexxion Bus 397 to Leidseplein. The bus runs every 15 minutes and takes you to the hostel in around 35 minutes. Parking We do advise our visitors to come by public transport There are no parking spaces at the hostel itself. In a nearby parking garage, parking spaces are available for €68.00 per day. Alternatively, you can also use the Park-and-Ride parking lots (P + R) at the Olympic Stadium or at Sloterijk train station (directions and prices can be found here). Local hotspots We're just a few minutes' walk from Leidseplein and Museumplein where you can shake cocktails at House of Bols. column32: Located in the heart of Amsterdam is the brand new five-star hotel and Amsterdam's best kept secret up to date. The Conservatorium offers 129 luxurious guest suites spread throughout 8 floors. Opening soon... Is located in the heart of Amsterdam is the brand new five-star hotel and Amsterdam's best kept secret up to date: the Conservatorium. It features exclusive amenities unlike any other hotel you have visited before, so extravagant in fact, that it brings luxury to a whole new level. Originally designed by Dutch architect Daniel Knuttel, this iconic building first began as the Rijkspostsbank at the close of the 19th century. The full 4000 square meters of space were then purchased in 1897, and an additional wing was added to the building in 1914. In 1978, the Rijkspostsbank moved office, and after initially being abandoned for five years, the building became the new home for the Sweelinck Conservatorium, originally comprised of three musical institutes. The modernized original architecture of the Conservatorium Hotel was upgraded to feature double walls, windows and doors which served to function as acoustic spaces for musical traning, up until the Sweenlick's departure in 1998. It remained neglected until 2008, when it was finally purchased by the team at Alrov, and with their visions for the epicurean traveller, the new Conservatorium was made a reality. The contemporary design of the Milan-based interior designer and architect, Piero Lissoni, focuses on the historical essence of the original iconic building. The award-winning Italian designer is best known for his simple lines, fabrics and subdued shades of grey, illuminated with bright accents. The Conservatorium combines a modernist style together with contemporary chic, but remains rooted upon its historical heritage in Amsterdam. Its features an undeniably attractive design, even for Dutch standards, projecting an immediate warmth - a surrounding aura of comfort and pure pleasure. Lissoni retains the essence of heritage and brings back original features for the interior of the stylish decor. Javanese teakwood floors and American pine are infused together in combination of old and modern elements, and the floors are lines with authentic asian rugs. The selected furniture of the interior, as well as for the guest suites, feature renowned Italian manufactures Kartell and Cassina to enhance the sophisticated, modern and international style. The Conservatorium Hotel Amsterdam offers 129 luxurious guest suites spread throughout 8 floors. The guest has the choice to arrange for a superior, deluxe or grand suite, with a stunning duplex feature available in some. The suites start at 30 square meters and expand to a maximum size of 170 square meters. Each guest suite includes complementary guest features, such as, wireless internet, a private bar, a daily newspaper, 24hr room service and an extravagant designer bathroom that features a flat-screen mirror TV. As it would be expected from a 5 star hotel wi-fi is free. This opulent package of amenities is unlike anything you have experienced before, it inhibits the true essence of extravagance for the pleasure-seeking modern hedonist. The Akasha Holistic Wellbeing Center is arguably one of the most exquisite features within the hotel. It offers separate gym and spa facilities for ideal balance, mindfulness and inner harmony. The Earth lounge generates organic foods and juices for total body cleansing and replenishment. The Water spa space encompasses soothing sounds, music and aroma therapy with high quality Watsupool Hydro Treatment, which you can enjoy whilst frolicking in the pool. The Fire gym offers classes on pilates, yoga and tai chi, giving you complete freedom to create your own fitness plan for overall health and well-being during your stay at the Conservatorium. Let's not forget the sumptuous dining menu, because no trip is complete without a memorable meal. Featuring mainly local and seasonal ingredients, the kitchen is under the direction of Dutch chef, Schilo van Coevorden. If you would like to have a drink or a snack with your hunny or your colleague, the Atrium boasts an informal brasserie with a mouth-watering plat du jour. The Tunes Restaurant & Bar by Schilo is open late-nights for dinner, featuring live DJ sets, a tapas bar - completely furnished with chic decor. You can also visit these luxurious dining spaces if you are not an official guest of the hotel, and get a small dose of high class to make your date a memorable one. Check-in is from 2PM and Chech-out is until 12:00 hours Even though The Netherlands is a country of many cat and dog owners pets are not allowed in the hotel All major credit card are excepted: Visa, Euro/Mastercard, American Express, Diners Club, Maestro Skins Cosmetics opened a shop in the Hotel Conservatorium. Skins Cosmetics has a large collection of great brands on thier shelves. They want not only to sell a high level product, but they also want high-level service. The whole concept of Skins Cosmetics is therefore focused on service and proper advice, something that is nowadays very popular among consumers which is why it fits perfectly in the Conservatorium. Do you really want something special, than get inspired with one of the experiences of Skins, you will love it! In addition to its inclusive en-suite features, the hotel is located within the cultural hub of the Museumplein district of Amsterdam. It is within short walking distance of city transit, independent restaurants, chic cafes and the infamous high-end shopping street is parallel to the hotel's location. The Conservatorium itself hosts 6 prime retail space for independent Dutch designers and features the highest quality in brands.

column32: museum of architecture ("Amsterdam School" style - Dutch expressionism) with former post office and historic museum appartement. Museum Het Schip bevindt zich in het fantasievolle volkswoningbouwcomplex dat is ontworpen door architect Michel de Klerk. Dit expressionistische woonblok is in 1919 gebouwd voor woningcorporatie Eigen Haard. Museum Het Schip is één van de twee locaties waarin wordt verteld over de Amsterdamse School. Draagt u Amsterdamse School Museum Het Schip en De Dageraad een warm hart toe en wilt u graag een steentje bijdragen? Dat kan! Als Vriend doneert u voor langere tijd én kunt u zo vaak langskomen als u wilt. U bent al Vriend vanaf € 45,00 per jaar (of een hoger bedrag naar keuze). De Amsterdamse School: het is geen school met leerlingen en de sporen ervan zijn lang niet alleen in Amsterdam te vinden. Maar wat wordt er dan wél mee bedoeld? Van 17 november 2023 t/m 1 september 2024 besteedt Museum Het Schip, 100 jaar na zijn dood, aandacht aan de grote inspirator van de Amsterdamse School, Michel de Klerk.

column32: At the border of ''Oud-West'' and the Canal District, this old-fashioned Marriott can offer a relatively attractive rate and still has a convenient location for exploring the city centre. Awards Welcome to Amsterdam Marriott Hotel Enjoy 5-star service in our city centre hotel in Amsterdam Experience a well-deserved escape at our hotel in Netherlands, Amsterdam. The Amsterdam Marriott Hotel is surrounded by stunning canals and exquisite architecture boasting an unparalleled city centre location across from the Leidseplein, just moments from Amsterdam's iconic attractions. Walk to the Anne Frank House, the Van Gogh Museum, Rijksmuseum and Vondelpark as well as upscale shopping, fine dining and entertainment destinations. If visiting for social events or business meetings, you'll revel in our hotel's premier facilities with 8,740 square feet of sophisticated event space. After a busy day in Amsterdam, unwind with a workout in our 24-hour fitness center, relax in our sauna or sample hand-crafted cocktails in our modern lounge. In the evening, dine on juicy steaks and fresh local produce at our delectable steakhouse before retreating to renovated accommodations with sleek bathrooms, stylish modern design and high-speed Wi-Fi. Discover unforgettable experiences at the Amsterdam Marriott Hotel. Modern Rooms With a Local Touch Redesigned Marriott Designed by the famous Dutch interior designer Piet Boon, our rooms are combining high-end functionality with the Amsterdam 'couleur locale' through smart technology and locally-inspired accents. Welcome to the Amsterdam hotel that sparks creativity, fuels imagination, and invites reflection and relaxation. Premium Rooms & Suites Experience the warmth and comfort of home in our stylish hotel in the city center of Amsterdam. Enjoy contemporary accommodations in different room categories all designed at the intersection of function and style. Sleep in plush feather beds, use high-tech amenities and be amazed by the view. Work and Recharge M Club Lounge Members enjoy 24/7 access to a private and exclusive space with free high-speed WiFi. Prep for your day over complimentary breakfast, work and recharge with snacks throughout the day, or relax over a drink and hors d’oeuvres in the evening. Experience the City of Canals Situated in the heart of the city center, the Amsterdam Marriott Hotel has the perfect location for every culture lover, so hop on a bike or put on a pair of comfy shoes and start walking. Contemporary & Adaptable Meeting Spaces Engaging Experiences Create an engaging experience for your next business conference, product launch, training session or an executive board meeting in Amsterdam. Natural daylight, dedicated event managers, stylish boardrooms, spacious meeting rooms and our Bonvoy Events platform will combine to ignite a truly inspired gathering. Learn MoreFitness Center Stay Fit 24/7. Our fitness club is open daily and features state-of-the-art equipment including cardiovascular, weight-resistance and free weights. Sauna Unwind in comfort and relax your body and mind in our saunas, located inside our fitness club. Perfect for a post-workout session or a tranquil pause in your day. Take A Look Around View Our Hotel in 3D Curious to see what our hotel looks like for your next stay or wanting to envision the space for an event? Take a look at our latest map where you can bring yourself anywhere in the Amsterdam Marriott Hotel in 3D. Getting Here Amsterdam Marriott Hotel Stadhouderskade 12, Amsterdam, Netherlands, 1054 ES not available NA On-Property: Private Car Service: Limousine/Van Service Nearby: Bus Station: Marnixstraat bus stationBus stop Leidseplein - bus 397 direct connection to and from Schiphol Tram stop Leidseplein - lines 1,2,5 to and from Central Station Subway Station: Amsterdam Central StationAmsterdam Rai Train Station: Our landmark hotel boasts an unparalleled city center location across from the Leidseplein, just moments from Amsterdam's iconic attractions. It is approximately a 30-40 minute journey from the airport to the hotel, depending on traffic. If you are traveling by car, please set your GPS location to 'Vondelstraat 1' for the entrance of the parking garage. ExploreFood for Your Journey Pick up a fresh snack on your way out or linger over a meal with us. From light bites to classics with a local twist, enjoy food that is familiar yet elevated beyond the expected.
